definitions: unable to think clearly, often from shock, surprise, or a blow
examples: The dazed boxer struggled to stand after the knockout punch
She looked dazed and confused after the car accident

definitions: amazed or impressed by something brilliant, impressive, or skillful
examples: The audience was dazzled by the magician's incredible performance
She felt dazzled by the celebrity's presence

definitions: so bright as to blind temporarily or cause discomfort to the eyes
extremely impressive, beautiful, or skillful in a way that amazes
examples: The dazzling sunlight reflected off the snow-covered mountains
She wore a dazzling white dress to the gala
Her dazzling performance earned a standing ovation
The company reported dazzling profits this quarter

definitions: having lost life; no longer living or functioning
extremely tired to the point of being unable to function
lacking activity, movement, excitement, or interest in a place or period
complete and absolute, used for emphasis with certain abstract concepts
examples: The dead bird lay motionless on the ground
They found a dead body in the river
I'm absolutely dead after running that marathon
She was dead tired from working double shifts
The town center was dead on Sunday afternoon
Business has been dead since the pandemic
He came to a dead stop at the intersection
She hit the target dead center

definitions: at a complete standstill with no possibility of progress due to disagreement
examples: The negotiations remained deadlocked after hours of discussion
The jury was deadlocked and unable to reach a verdict

definitions: capable of causing or likely to cause death; fatal
extremely boring or dull to an unbearable degree
extremely accurate or effective in achieving an aim
examples: The snake's venom contains deadly toxins
Cancer remains one of the most deadly diseases
The lecture was absolutely deadly and half the class fell asleep
The deadly silence stretched on for minutes
She has deadly aim with a bow and arrow
His deadly accurate predictions shocked everyone

definitions: deliberately impassive or expressionless, especially when being humorous
examples: His deadpan delivery of the joke made it even funnier
She maintained a deadpan expression throughout the absurd conversation

definitions: lacking the power of hearing or having impaired hearing
unwilling to listen or respond to something, deliberately ignoring
examples: She has been deaf since birth and communicates through sign language
The explosion left him temporarily deaf in one ear
The government remained deaf to the protesters' demands
He turned a deaf ear to their warnings

definitions: so loud as to make it impossible to hear anything else
examples: The deafening roar of the jet engines hurt their ears
A deafening silence followed the shocking announcement

definitions: loved and cherished; regarded with deep affection
costing a lot of money; expensive
examples: She received a letter from her dear friend
This necklace was dear to her grandmother's heart
The restaurant was too dear for our budget
Everything is getting dearer these days

definitions: resembling or suggestive of death in appearance or manner
examples: A deathly silence fell over the courtroom
Her face turned deathly pale when she heard the news

definitions: reduced in quality, value, or character; degraded or corrupted
examples: The debased currency was nearly worthless
His debased morals shocked the community

definitions: open to dispute or argument; not certain or agreed upon
examples: Whether the policy improved things is highly debatable
It's debatable whether we should proceed with the plan

definitions: causing serious impairment of strength or ability to function normally
examples: She suffers from debilitating migraines several times a month
The debilitating effects of the disease became apparent

definitions: characterized by moral or cultural decline; corrupt or degenerate
luxuriously self-indulgent, especially with rich food or comfort
examples: Critics called the artwork decadent and morally bankrupt
The decadent society collapsed under its own corruption
They enjoyed a decadent chocolate cake for dessert
The spa offered a decadent weekend retreat package

definitions: having had the head cut off or removed from the body
examples: The decapitated statue was found in the ruins
Police discovered a decapitated body in the woods

definitions: having rotted or decomposed through natural processes; deteriorated
examples: The decayed wood crumbled at the slightest touch
His decayed teeth required extensive dental work

definitions: recently dead, especially used as a formal or legal term
examples: The deceased person's will was read to the family
She is the deceased patient's next of kin

definitions: guilty of or involving deceit; deliberately misleading or fraudulent
examples: His deceitful behavior destroyed their trust
She exposed the company's deceitful marketing practices

definitions: conforming to accepted standards of morality or respectability
of acceptable or satisfactory quality, though not outstanding
examples: He's a decent person who always helps his neighbors
She insisted on wearing decent clothes to the interview
They serve decent food at reasonable prices
He earns a decent salary for his experience level

definitions: transferred from central to local authority; distributed rather than concentrated
examples: The decentralised system gives more power to local offices
They adopted a decentralised management structure

definitions: transferred from central to local authority; distributed rather than concentrated
examples: The company uses a decentralized decision-making process
Blockchain enables decentralized financial systems

definitions: giving an appearance or impression different from the true one; misleading
examples: The calm water had deceptive currents underneath
His deceptive simplicity masked complex calculations

definitions: clear and definite; leaving no room for doubt or question
examples: There was a decided improvement in her performance
He spoke with a decided accent from the region

definitions: settling an issue or bringing about a definite result
examples: He scored the deciding goal in overtime
The deciding factor was the company's reputation

definitions: shedding leaves annually, as certain trees and shrubs do
examples: Deciduous trees lose their leaves in autumn
The deciduous forest was bare in winter

definitions: relating to or denoting a system of numbers based on ten
examples: The decimal system uses ten digits from zero to nine
Convert the fraction to decimal form

definitions: succeeded in understanding or interpreting something unclear or coded
examples: The ancient text was finally deciphered by linguists
Scientists deciphered the genetic code decades ago

definitions: settling an issue quickly and producing a definite result
having crucial importance in determining an outcome
examples: She took decisive action to solve the crisis
His decisive leadership saved the company
The battle proved decisive in winning the war
It was a decisive moment in history

definitions: denoting a statement or sentence that declares something
examples: Write a simple declarative sentence about the weather
The declarative mood is used for statements

definitions: openly acknowledged or announced officially or formally
examples: He is a declared candidate for the presidency
The declared value of the goods was incorrect

definitions: officially declared no longer secret and made available to the public
examples: The declassified documents revealed government secrets
Declassified files shed light on the operation

definitions: adorned or embellished with ornaments or decorative elements
honored with medals or awards for achievement or service
examples: The decorated Christmas tree sparkled with lights
She lived in a beautifully decorated apartment
The decorated war veteran received another honor
He was the most decorated athlete in school history

definitions: serving to make something look more attractive; ornamental
examples: The vase is purely decorative and not meant for use
She added decorative pillows to the sofa

definitions: made smaller or fewer in size, amount, intensity, or degree
examples: The decreased funding affected many programs
He noticed decreased appetite after starting medication

definitions: becoming smaller or fewer in size, amount, or degree over time
examples: The decreasing temperatures signal winter's approach
There's been decreasing interest in the program

definitions: officially ordered or established by decree or authority
examples: The decreed changes took effect immediately
The king's decreed punishment was harsh

definitions: worn out or ruined because of age or neglect; in very poor condition
examples: The decrepit building was scheduled for demolition
His decrepit car barely made it up the hill

definitions: devoted to a task, purpose, or cause with wholehearted commitment
exclusively allocated to or intended for a particular purpose
examples: She's a dedicated teacher who works evenings and weekends
The dedicated volunteers made the event possible
They have a dedicated server for customer data
This dedicated parking space is for disabled visitors only

definitions: able to be deducted, especially from taxable income or tax to be paid
examples: Charitable donations are tax deductible
Business expenses are deductible from your income

definitions: characterized by reasoning from general principles to specific conclusions
examples: She used deductive reasoning to solve the mystery
The deductive method starts with a theory

definitions: becoming deeper in physical depth, intensity, or understanding
examples: The deepening crisis required immediate action
Her deepening voice indicated maturity

definitions: damaging the good reputation of someone through false statements
examples: The newspaper was sued for defamatory articles
His defamatory remarks led to legal action

definitions: having lost in a contest, battle, or struggle
feeling overwhelmed and without hope or energy to continue
examples: The defeated army retreated from the battlefield
The defeated candidate congratulated the winner
She looked defeated after receiving the bad news
His defeated attitude worried his friends

definitions: imperfect or faulty; having a defect that impairs function
examples: The defective product was recalled by the manufacturer
They discovered defective wiring in the building

definitions: without defense or protection; unable to defend oneself; vulnerable
examples: The defenceless villagers fled from the attackers
She felt defenceless against their accusations

definitions: currently holding a title or position and defending it in competition
examples: The defending champion lost in the first round
Our defending position proved advantageous

definitions: without defense or protection; unable to defend oneself; vulnerable
examples: The defenseless puppy needed immediate care
They attacked defenseless civilians

definitions: justifiable by argument; capable of being defended logically
able to be protected from physical attack or invasion
examples: Her position was morally defensible despite criticism
The theory is scientifically defensible
The castle occupied a defensible position on the hill
They retreated to a more defensible location

definitions: used or intended to defend or protect from attack
anxious to defend oneself against criticism; oversensitive
examples: The team adopted a defensive strategy
They built defensive walls around the city
She became defensive when questioned about her work
His defensive attitude made communication difficult
